node.title: Why does the default preconditoning(Block Diagonal Preconditioner) PMat not diagonal？
node.bodyText:
Hello all,
May I ask why does the output preprocessor matrix (PMat) in my program not block diagonal? Attached below is my program and the PMat.
[GlobalParams]
displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
temperature = temperature
volumetric_locking_correction = true
[]
[Mesh]
type = GeneratedMesh
dim = 2
nx = 4
ny = 4
xmax = 0.06 # Length of test chamber
ymax = 0.06 # Test chamber radius
[]
[Variables]
[./disp_x]
[../]
[./disp_y]
[../]
[temperature]
initial_condition = 300 # Start at room temperature
[]
[]
[Kernels]
[./TensorMechanics]
use_automatic_differentiation = true
[../]
[heat_conduction]
type = ADHeatConduction
variable = temperature
[]
[heat_conduction_time_derivative]
type = ADHeatConductionTimeDerivative
variable = temperature
[]
[]
[BCs]
[confinex]
type = DirichletBC
variable = disp_x
value = 0
boundary = 'left'
[]
[confiney]
type = DirichletBC
variable = disp_y
value = 0
boundary = left
[]
[inlet_temperature]
type = DirichletBC
variable = temperature
boundary = left
value = 500 # (K)
[]
[outlet_temperature]
type = DirichletBC
variable = temperature
boundary = right
value = 300 # (K)
[]
[]
[Materials]
[./elasticity_tensor]
type = ADComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
youngs_modulus = 300e9
poissons_ratio = 0.222
[../]
[./strain]
type = ADComputeSmallStrain
eigenstrain_names = eigenstrain
# List of eigenstrains to be applied in this strain calculation
[../]
[./thermal_strain]
type = ADComputeThermalExpansionEigenstrain
stress_free_temperature =300
thermal_expansion_coeff = 8e-6
eigenstrain_name = eigenstrain
[../]
[./stress]
type = ADComputeLinearElasticStress
[../]
[./heat]
type = ADHeatConductionMaterial
specific_heat =900
thermal_conductivity = 27
[../]
[density]
type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
prop_names = 'density'
prop_values = 3900
[]
[]
[Postprocessors]
[single_nodal_temperature]
type = PointValue
point = '0.01 0.01 0'
variable = temperature
[]
[]
[Executioner]
type = Transient
scheme = bdf2
end_time= 30
solve_type =PJFNK
petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type -ksp_gmres_restart'
petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg 101'
[]
[Outputs]
exodus = true
csv = true
[./console]
type = Console
output_file=true
[../]
[]

Hello
you have coupling between 3 variables so there are diagonal terms in the Jacobian
the default preconditioning will use the Jacobian for PJFNK
Guillaume

node.title: [PorousFlow]__Debugging
node.bodyText:
**Dear all,
When I use the PorousFlow module running my input, I get the following errors.**
"YOUR APPLICATION TERMINATED WITH THE EXIT STRING: Segmentation fault (signal 11)
This typically refers to a problem with your application. Please see the FAQ page for debugging suggestions"
So I follow the Debugging document, and I get the following tips:
Thread 1 "porous_flow-dbg" received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
0x0000155554ac121c in PorousFlowMaterial::sizeNodalProperties (this=0x262fa40) at /home/projects/moose/modules/porous_flow/src/materials/PorousFlowMaterial.C:147
147         props_old[prop_id]->resize(new_size);
Missing separate debuginfos, use: yum debuginfo-install keyutils-libs-1.5.10-6.el8.x86_64 krb5-libs-1.18.2-9.el8_4.x86_64 libX11-1.6.8-4.el8.x86_64 libXau-1.0.9-3.el8.x86_64 libblkid-2.32.1-27.el8.x86_64 libcom_err-1.45.6-2.el8_4.x86_64 libmount-2.32.1-27.el8.x86_64 libpciaccess-0.14-1.el8.x86_64 libselinux-2.9-5.el8.x86_64 libtirpc-1.1.4-4.el8.x86_64 libunwind-1.3.1-3.el8.x86_64 libuuid-2.32.1-27.el8.x86_64 libxcb-1.13.1-1.el8.x86_64 libxml2-2.9.7-9.el8_4.2.x86_64 openssl-libs-1.1.1g-16.el8_4.x86_64 pcre2-10.32-2.el8.x86_64 systemd-libs-239-45.el8_4.15.x86_64 xz-libs-5.2.4-4.el8_4.x86_64 zlib-1.2.11-18.el8_4.x86_64
How can I solve this problem? Thanks for your help in advance.
J

This is a pretty low-level material in porous flow. Can you post a minimal example that demonstrates this?
Have you made your own material or are you using just the standard materials available in the module?
For those reading along, this should be fixed by #23672

For those reading along, this should be fixed by #23672

Thanks a lot, Chris! It works!

node.title: DED and PBF AM simulation in MOOSE
node.bodyText:
I recently saw the announcement of MALAMUTE, an application focused on modeling and simulation of additive manufacturing processes. I was wondering whether this application is available and if not, when will it be released? And I was also wondering whether it will be able to simulate DED and PBF processes.
https://inl.gov/article/simulation-code-probes-microscale-mysteries-of-advanced-manufacturing/
Thank you!
@cticenhour

Hello, and thank you for your interest! MALAMUTE is focused on advanced manufacturing processes, not just additive, and we have some additive manufacturing capability coming online soon. Currently we can simulate aspects of electrothermal processes for electric field assisted sintering alongside laser-induced surface deformation and pool dynamics. DED capabilities will be coming online from several members of the development team this year - the points of contact for those efforts would be @dewenyushu and @jiangwen84 if they want to chime in.
MALAMUTE is currently a licensed INL code, which means you should first contact the INL Technology Deployment office (see https://inl.gov/inl-initiatives/technology-deployment/) in order to obtain a license.
I wanted to announce an important change to the status of MALAMUTE - it is now open source! It can now be found at https://github.com/idaholab/malamute.

node.title: Rectangular domain with circular cutout
node.bodyText: Hi all, I'm looking to generate a rectangular domain with a circular cutout for vortex shedding analysis. What's the best way to do this using (existing) mesh generators? (@AlbertJP7) Maybe @GiudGiud has an idea?

Use this
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/ConcentricCircleMeshGenerator.html
then delete the circle(s) block(s)
Guillaume
Or maybe this (#13696) if the concentric circle mesh is not ideal?
Maybe I need to add a blocks parameter? Otherwise I do not see how to directly control the block name/ID of the created circle and consequently know what block to delete

the blocks have different ids anyway
but yes a blocks parameter would be welcome!

Hmm, I'm not sure how I'm gonna make this work. I want to make a domain for simulating vortex shedding for which we want a long region after the circle such that outlet boundary condition does not affect the flow around the sphere. I'm not sure how I'm going to be able to stitch such an exit region (which I was thinking I would create just with a GeneratedMeshGenerator) with the (square - circle) region that the ConcentricCircleMeshGenerator gives me. Hard for me to see those nodes getting lined up
(this taken from our concentric circle mesh generator test)
@grmnptr would you use gmsh for this mesh or would you suggest another open source tool?
Yea @AlbertJP7, I think we'll just go with gmsh on this one (probably don't need this long of an exit length though)
Might need to think about boundary layers around the circle (and maybe along the walls)

the mesh is regular on the sides on the square, you should be able to stitch it alright.
You can also create boundary layers naturally by having an extra ring

I would use Salome, but gmsh is fine. You can definitely fit a structured mesh on this. Add a square around the circle and connect the corners to the circle that way you will end up with four quadrants which can be refined close to the circle.

node.title: Model solves with longer timesteps, but not shorter ones.
node.bodyText:
Hello
I have a real conundrum which seems counter-intiutive to how I though MOOSE works.
I have an input file which runs quickly and efficiently when default timestep dt = 1s.  It takes about a minute to do 1000 timesteps with all timesteps = 1s, i.e. not cutbacks are needed.
If I change the defualt timestep to dt = 0.1s, then after a few steps it starts cutting back the timestep to even shorter times, struggles to solve and ultimately reaches the minimum timestep value and fails to complete the solve.
If I make dt = 10s, it solves quickly with no cutbacks.  The solution is pretty much the same as for dt = 1s, but coarser as expected.
I had always thought that if a solve was struggling, making timesteps shorter would help with this.  But here exactly the opposite is happening!
Has anybody else seen this anomalous behaviour?  Any ideas on what is causing it and how to fix it?
Thanks!

Hello
Could you please attach the convergence log for the 0.1s case and the regular case too
Thank you
Guillaume
Thanks for the quick reply!  Can you tell where to find or how to generate the convergence log?  I'll try to get this done later today - but more likely tomorrow.
it's what appears on the console when you run the input basically. If you can attach them rather than paste them

Hi
These are the outputs for the start of each run.  I hope I have attached them OK.
You will see that with dt=1s, the solve gets to 60s with no problems or cutbacks.
With dt=0.1s, it starts having to cut back at 1.4s.
ConvergenceLog1_dt=1,0s_NoCutback_SolveSucceeds.txt
ConvergenceLog2_dt=0,1s_Cutback_SolveFails.txt

It seems the line search dies with the 0.1s timesteps.
Do you mind turning it off? With line_search = none in Executioner
With regards to finding the culprit, can you please paste your executioner block here
also can you turn on variable residual output. one can use show_var_residual_norms in Debug block
https://mooseframework.inl.gov//syntax/Debug/index.html

Thanks!  I will try this.
Here's the Executioner block before making the changes you suggest:
[Executioner]
  scheme = bdf2
  type = Transient
  solve_type = NEWTON
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_type -snes_type -pc_factor_shift_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu bcgs newtonls NONZERO'
  automatic_scaling = true
  compute_scaling_once = false
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-15 # This should avoid solve failures when close to steady-state
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-5
  dt = 0.1 # s 
  timestep_tolerance = 1e-3 # s
  end_time = 10 # s
[]

Attached now is the convergence log with "line_search = none" included.
The lines stating "Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_LINE_SEARCH ..." are no longer there (as expected I suppose), but the solve still fails after 1.4 s.
There's also an extract of the log from 1.3 s with the Debug residuals command included.
ConvergenceLog3_dt=0,1s_LineSearchOff_SolveFails.txt
ConvergenceLog3a_dt=0,1s_LineSearchOff_DebugResidualsOnFrom_t=1,3s_SolveFails.txt

Can you turn off re-scaling on every iteration
compute_scaling_once = false
by making it true.
This is changing the goal for reducing residual in each variable on every time step .
If we look around the failure, you have a lot of variables and some of them are very well converged already.
I think the key here will be to come up with a good scaling strategy.
You can either try manual scaling (in Variables block) or try to group variables in scaling_groups, in the executioner parameters
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/executioners/Steady.html#613ee2f4-a2b2-400a-953d-62f040f096dc
Time Step 14, time = 1.30625, dt = 0.00625

Performing automatic scaling calculation

 0 Nonlinear |R| = 6.900904e-06
    |residual|_2 of individual variables:
                   C_Hm:     3.72346e-20
                   C_Htr1_1: 2.43051e-06
                   C_Htr1_2: 8.49783e-08
                   C_Htr1_3: 6.43852e-06
                   C_Htr1_4: 5.03338e-07
                   C_Htr1_5: 2.78968e-09
                   C_Htr1_6: 2.17528e-12
                   C_Dm:     8.74736e-24
                   C_Dtr1_1: 4.90283e-10
                   C_Dtr1_2: 1.70592e-11
                   C_Dtr1_3: 1.2877e-09
                   C_Dtr1_4: 1.00667e-10
                   C_Dtr1_5: 5.57936e-13
                   C_Dtr1_6: 4.35055e-16

Changing compute_scaling_once = true doesn't seem to make any difference.  It still breaks down after 1.3 s.
The comment about scaling agrees with what colleagues here have suggested.
I'll need to understand more about how this works, so will take a look at the links.
Are they any other resources on the MOOSE website or elsewhere which explain scaling calculations and how to apply manual scaling?  It would be really helpful to see a simple example which shows what calculations are being made by the solver, and how scaling helps to make these easier (or even possible) to calculate.

There is not good documentation on scaling
This is the best we have
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/source/systems/NonlinearSystemBase.html#scaling
The list of parameters of the executioner shows all the options you have.
Sometimes scaling based on the residual instead of the Jacobian helps
Sometimes including off-diagonal terms also help, we've added that for scaling the Navier Stokes equations

Many thanks for all your help with this.  It looks like I need to go and do some reading to understand what might be causing my problem - and if possible fix it.
I need to take my understanding of the relevant mathematical processes applied in scaling or normalisation from the equivalent of A-level or simple undergraduate statistics in the UK (high school and college in the US?) to what MOOSE is doing when scaling solves to try and achieve an efficient and accurate solution.  I come from a materials science and engineering background, so not familiar with a lot of the applied math(s) and computer science terminology which is used.
Are there any books or other resources you can recommend?  How have others developed this knowledge, or does it usually just get learnt "on-the-job" while using the tools?

node.title: Zero pivot with invertible matrix
node.bodyText:
Dear moose users and developers,
I am facing a quite strange behaviour using Moose: it outputs a ZERO_PIVOT error message but my jacobian matrix, read in python and inverted with numpy, is clearly invertible (below is an example with a very small mesh) :
0 Nonlinear |R| = 1.062497e+03
      0 Linear |R| = 1.062497e+03
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_PC_FAILED iterations 0
                 PC failed due to FACTOR_NUMERIC_ZEROPIVOT 
Mat Object: () 1 MPI processes
  type: seqaij
row 0: (0, 0.)  (1, 1.66667)  (2, 0.)  (3, 0.)  (4, 0.833333)  (5, 0.) 
row 1: (0, 1.66667)  (1, 0.)  (2, 0.)  (3, 0.833333)  (4, 0.)  (5, 0.) 
row 2: (0, 0.)  (1, 0.)  (2, 1.66667)  (3, 0.)  (4, 0.)  (5, 0.833333)

row 4: (0, 0.833333)  (1, 0.)  (2, 0.)  (3, 1.66667)  (4, 0.)  (5, 0.) 
row 5: (0, 0.)  (1, 0.)  (2, 0.833333)  (3, 0.)  (4, 0.)  (5, 1.66667) 
row 6: (6, 1.9) 
row 7: (7, 1.9)

row 9: (8, 0.)  (9, 1.)  (10, 0.)  (11, 0.)  (12, 0.)  (13, 0.)  (14, 0.)  (15, 0.) 
row 10: (8, 0.)  (9, 0.)  (10, 1.)  (11, 0.)  (12, 0.)  (13, 0.)  (22, 0.)  (23, 0.) 
row 11: (8, 0.)  (9, 0.)  (10, 0.)  (11, 1.)  (12, 0.)  (13, 0.)  (14, 0.)  (15, 0.)  (22, 0.)  (23, 0.)  (24, 0.)  (25, 0.)  (26, 0.)  (27, 0.) 
row 12: (8, 0.)  (9, 0.)  (10, 0.)  (11, 0.)  (12, 1.)  (13, 0.)  (14, 0.)  (15, 0.)

row 16: (16, 1.)  (17, 0.)  (18, 0.)  (19, 0.)  (20, 0.)  (21, 0.)  (22, 0.)  (23, 0.) 
row 17: (14, 0.)  (15, 0.)  (16, 0.)  (17, 1.)  (18, 0.)  (19, 0.)  (20, 0.)  (21, 0.) 
row 18: (14, 0.)  (15, 0.)  (16, 0.)  (17, 0.)  (18, 1.)  (19, 0.)  (20, 0.)  (21, 0.)  (22, 0.)  (23, 0.)  (24, 0.)  (25, 0.)  (26, 0.)  (27, 0.)

There is an old post on this subject (#18893), but my variables run kernels only on blocks where they are defined.
Here is my input file:
[Mesh]

  # We read the gmsh 3D mesh
  [gmsh3D]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = "../mesh/mesh_dev_1.msh"
    #allow_renumbering = false
  []

  # We read the gmsh 1D mesh
  [gmsh1D]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = "../mesh/mesh_dev_2.msh"
    #allow_renumbering = false
  []

  # We merge the 3D and 1D mesh
  [merge]
    type = MeshCollectionGenerator
    inputs = 'gmsh1D gmsh3D'
  []

  # We rename the boundaries
  [merge_boundaries_renamed]
    type = RenameBoundaryGenerator
    input = merge
    old_boundary = '1   2   3   4   5   6   7          9           10         '
    new_boundary = 'XM  XP  YM  YP  ZM  ZP  PIPE_WALL  PIPE_INPUT  PIPE_OUTPUT'
  []

  # We rename the subdomains (also called "blocks")
  [final_mesh]
    type = RenameBlockGenerator
    input = merge_boundaries_renamed
    old_block = '8     11  '
    new_block = 'SOIL  PIPE'
    show_info = true
  []

[]

# We put here parameters which are used by several kernels (to avoid repetitions)
# -------------------------------------------------------------------------------

[GlobalParams]
  air_pressure     = p
  air_velocity     = v
  air_temperature  = ta
  soil_temperature = ts
[]

##################################################################################
# VARIABLES
##################################################################################

[Variables]

  # Variable describing the behaviour of air

  # Air pressure

  [p]
    family = LAGRANGE
    order  = FIRST
    block  = "PIPE"
  []

  # Air velocity

  [v]
    family = LAGRANGE
    order  = FIRST
    block  = "PIPE"
  []

  # Air temperature (must exist in the block SOIL to calculate the interface convective kernel)

  [ta]
    family = LAGRANGE
    order  = FIRST
    block  = "PIPE"
  []

  # Variable describing the behaviour of soil (must exist in the block PIPE to calculate the interface convective kernel)

  # Soil temperature

  [ts]
    family = LAGRANGE
    order  = FIRST
    block  = "PIPE SOIL"
  []

[]

##################################################################################
# USER OBJECTS
##################################################################################

[UserObjects]

  [well_wall_nodal_pairing]
    type = EAHE_Well_To_Wall_Nodal_Pairing
    execute_on = 'INITIAL'
    block = 'PIPE'
    wall_boundary_name = 'PIPE_WALL'
    pipe_radius = 0.10
    pipe_radius_tolerance = 0.001
    verbose = true
  []

[]

##################################################################################
# MATERIALS
##################################################################################

[Materials]

  # Soil

  [soil]   # soil properties must exist in PIPE because of the interface convective term
    type  = EAHE_Soil
    block = 'PIPE SOIL'
    soil_conductivity = 20.0
  []

  # Pipe

  [pipe]
    type  = EAHE_Pipe
    block = 'PIPE'
    air_specific_mass               = 1.371
    air_dynamic_viscosity           = 1.651E-5
    air_conductivity                = 0.0242
    air_specific_heat_at_constant_p = 1005.0
    nusselt_a                       = 0.023
    nusselt_n                       = 0.80
    nusselt_m                       = 0.33
    reynolds_velocity               = 2.0
    reynolds_length                 = 0.17
    interface_width                 = 0.002
  []

[]

##################################################################################
# KERNELS CALLS
##################################################################################

[NodalKernels]

  # Kernel to compute the mean value of the soil temperature on the wall and affect it to the current node

  [soil_temperature_in_well_projection]
    type  = EAHE_Get_Wall_Nodal_Mean_Value
    variable = ts
    block = "PIPE"
    pairing_nodes_uo = well_wall_nodal_pairing
    penalty = 1.9
  []

[]


[Kernels]

  # Kernels for the soil energy balance

  [soil_energy_balance]
    type      = EAHE_Soil_Energy_Balance
    variable  = ts
    block     = "SOIL"
  []

  # Kernels for the pipe mass balance

  [pipe_mass_balance]
    type      = EAHE_Pipe_Mass_Balance
    variable  = p
    block     = "PIPE"
  []

  # Kernels for the pipe momentum balance

  [pipe_momentum_balance]
    type      = EAHE_Pipe_Momentum_Balance
    variable  = v
    block     = "PIPE"
  []

  # Kernels for the pipe energy balance

  [pipe_energy_balance]
    type      = EAHE_Pipe_Energy_Balance
    variable  = ta
    block     = "PIPE"
  []

[]

##################################################################################
# BOUNDARY CONDITIONS
##################################################################################

[BCs]

  # Soil up and down BCs

  [soil_temperature_top]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = ts
    boundary = "ZP"
    value = 288.0
  []

  [soil_temperature_bottom]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = ts
    boundary = "ZM"
    value = 295.0
  []

[]

##################################################################################
# SOLVER AND PRECONDITIONER CONFIGURATION
##################################################################################

[Executioner]
  type       = Steady
  solve_type = NEWTON
  line_search = basic
  [./TimeStepper]
    type = ConstantDT
    dt = 1.0
  [../]
[]

[Preconditioning]
 [./hypre]
   type = SMP
   full = true
   petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type
                          -ksp_type -ksp_rtol -ksp_max_it
                          -snes_type -snes_atol -snes_rtol -snes_max_it
                          -ksp_gmres_restart'
   petsc_options_value = 'lu boomeramg
                          fgmres    1e-8  2000
                          newtonls 1.0E-8   1e-9  60
                          101'
   petsc_options = '-ksp_view_mat'

 [../]
[]

##################################################################################
# OUTPUT CONFIGURATION
##################################################################################

[Outputs]
  # print_linear_residuals = false
  perf_graph = true
  [exodus]
    type = Exodus
    file_base = eahe
    # execute_on = 'TIMESTEP_END'
    # execute_on = 'INITIAL LINEAR TIMESTEP_END'
  []
  csv = true
  [dofmap]
    type = DOFMap
    execute_on = 'initial'
  []
[]


I really don't understand what is happening, does anyone can provide any idea ?

Hello
Is the application open source? (to see if I can run this)
How did you converge to these petsc options? Did you try simpler ones like LU with a mumps mat_solver_package
Guillaume

Invertible matrix isn't necessarily LU factorizable. Your rows 0, 1, 3, 4 have zero diagonals. You could try adding a small nonzero to the diagonals (there is a petsc option for that) or adding a small nonzero to your equations corresponding to those rows.
-pc_factor_shift NONZERO for the former

Hello,
I feel a little bit guilty of missing this basic mathematical result... Anyway, adding a little diagonal jacobian entry (~1.0-9) solved the problem .
Thank you very much for your answers.

node.title: PBP preconditioner
node.bodyText:
Hello all,
What parameters can be set for preprocessor when using PBP? Where else do I need to find all the available parameters? thank you.

Hello
list of parameters at the bottom of this page
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/preconditioners/PhysicsBasedPreconditioner.html
Guillaume
thank you
it s not super-finished in terms of documentation but examples (at bottom of page) will help too
thanks

node.title: Preconditioners in Moose
node.bodyText:
Hello all,
I'd like to ask you about the difference between SMP,FSP and PBP. Can you explain how to choose these preprocessors? Are there any references or specific examples? Thank you very much.

Hello
Please refer to their respective documentation
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Preconditioning/index.html
You need to search the litterature for the postprocessing that works for your problem then reproduce it with one of the MOOSE ones.
For example, for the Navier Stokes equations, a field split between pressure and velocity is a published solution we have tried in MOOSE NS
Guillaume
thank you very much

node.title: Should v and displacements in the MatDiffusion Kernel behave similarly ?
node.bodyText:
Hi
I am trying to understand the difference between the displacements and the v in the MatDiffusion kernel here (and other Diffusion kernels as well). What I initially understood is that both of them are couplable_variables, am I right? If that is the case, why are they behaving differently? Please see below the input file that can reproduce my conclusion (replace v by displacements and the results will not be the same)
Another issue is w.r.t the jacobian computation when explicitly specifying v=variable (the default nonlinear variable).  As indicated in the documentation, if the v is not specified, the default nonlinear variable will be used for v (i.e. v=variable). Now, if the two lines in the kernel block were uncommented, it will result in an incorrect solution. However, if the ADMatDiffusion is used, it results in the correct solution, indicating the jacobian is not computed properly when explicitly specifying v=variable.
I can work on a fix for these and submit a PR after confirming it and if you think it is worth fixing it.
Please see the expected (correct solution below):

[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 1
  xmin = 0
  xmax = 1
  nx = 1000
[]

[Variables]
  [ui]
  []
  [ur]
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [uxr_left_1]
    type = CoupledVarNeumannBC
    variable = ur
    boundary = 'left'
    v = ui
    coef = 99.627 
  []
  [uxr_left_2]
    type = CoupledVarNeumannBC
    variable = ur
    boundary = 'left'
    v = ur
    coef = -4.969 
  []

  [uxi_left_1]
    type = CoupledVarNeumannBC
    variable = ui
    boundary = 'left'
    v = ui
    coef = -4.969
  []
  [uxi_left_2]
    type = CoupledVarNeumannBC
    variable = ui
    boundary = 'left'
    v = ur
    coef = -99.627 
  []
  [right_real]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = ur
    value = 1
    boundary = right
  []
  [right_imaginery]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = ui
    value = 0
    boundary = right
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [sigma_rr]
    type = MatDiffusion
    variable = ur
    diffusivity = 1
    # v = ur
  []
  [sigma_ii]
    type = MatDiffusion
    variable = ur
    diffusivity = -0.1
    v = ui
  []
  [sigma_ri]
    type = MatDiffusion
    variable = ui
    diffusivity = 1
    # v = ui
  []
  [sigma_ir]
    type = MatDiffusion
    variable = ui
    diffusivity = 0.1
    v = ur
  []
  [reaction_real]
    type = Reaction
    variable = ur
    rate = -10000
  []
  [reaction_imag]
    type = Reaction
    variable = ui
    rate = -10000
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  solve_type = LINEAR
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu'
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

Hello
Displacements is used to represent the deformation of the mesh, not a field living on the mesh.
Displacements affect the volume of elements for example. It s more involved than just solving for a field
Please submit a patch if you have found a bug. We can examine it in the PR
Guillaume

node.title: Generating mesh for a unit cell in MOOSE
node.bodyText: The attached mesh is generated in cubit, which contains six 1/3 cylinders, a central hole, and a hexagon excluding the 1/3 cylinders. I wonder if this geometry can be directly generated and meshed in the MOOSE reactor module. Thanks.

Hello
I think we can do this geometry.
Overall it will be:

a hexagonconcentriccirclegenerator for the center with a big circle
same generator for the 6 other positions
an assembly generator to tie them all together
an hexagon trimmer with the peripheral option to cut on the circles of the 6 external positions

Guillaume

I found that adding "quad_center_elements = true"  causes Segmentation fault: 11, as below. Setting it to false generates the mesh fine. Any ideas why setting the quad_center_elements crashes my code? Thanks.
[hex_1]
    type = PolygonConcentricCircleMeshGenerator
    num_sides = 6
    num_sectors_per_side = '10 10 10 10 10 10'
    # background_intervals = 10
    # background_block_ids = 20
    # background_block_names = background
    polygon_size = 3.0
    polygon_size_style = radius
    preserve_volumes = off # on
    flat_side_up = true
    quad_center_elements = true
  []
@miaoyinb if you could please have a look

In addition, the central hole is not of the same size as the 6 external circles. In this case, can we still use the hexagonal assembly to tie these circles together? If not, is my understanding correct that we may not use an hexagon trimmer to cut on the 6 external circles?

yes. The central circle is not determining the boundary mesh
For the trimmer there may be some limitations on when you can use it, but I think there's a workaround. Please let us know once you reach there

I found that adding "quad_center_elements = true" causes Segmentation fault: 11, as below. Setting it to false generates the mesh fine. Any ideas why setting the quad_center_elements crashes my code? Thanks.
[hex_1]
    type = PolygonConcentricCircleMeshGenerator
    num_sides = 6
    num_sectors_per_side = '10 10 10 10 10 10'
    # background_intervals = 10
    # background_block_ids = 20
    # background_block_names = background
    polygon_size = 3.0
    polygon_size_style = radius
    preserve_volumes = off # on
    flat_side_up = true
    quad_center_elements = true
  []


This should be a bug. I will fix it.
It should work fine if you uncomment # background_block_ids = 20 before the fix.
#23652 Thanks for reporting the bug.
Uncommenting # background_block_ids = 20 works. Thanks for providing the workaround.
The fix for the bug has been merged. Your original input should also work with the most updated MOOSE next branch.
use the BlockDeletionGenerator
